Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Response of Premixed Swirling Flames to Transverse Acoustic Excitation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Combustion instabilities have emerged as the single largest challenge in the development of clean combustion systems for power generation, aircraft engines, and other industrial heating applications. These instabilities cause significant damage to engine hardware, reduce engine operability, and increase production of harmful pollutants. Understanding how flame's respond to acoustic oscillations is a critical, but poorly understood, problem at the root of the instabilities and the focus of this work. This work will utilize state of the art, high speed laser diagnostics to probe the unsteady flow and flame during oscillatory combustion and compare these results to predictive models. The project will directly support one graduate student, while also leveraging other funds to support additional project participants, including undergraduate students and a summer high school teacher. The program has been structured such that research, education, and service are simultaneously performed. For example, the PI will organize opportunities for graduate students to present their research to high school classes and explain the exciting applications of science and mathematics. This program encourages high school students to pursue careers in science and provides the graduate students with teaching experience and community exposure.

The knowledge gained from this work will lead to improved understanding of the unsteady fluid mechanics of combusting flows, and how the flames in these devices respond to acoustic excitation. In turn, this fundamental knowledge will enable the design of robust, long lasting energy systems that are low emissions. This work has the strong endorsement and financial support from its industrial partner. The collaboration is structured such that the NSF program will be used to develop diagnostic tools, analysis approaches, and physical constructs for key flame and flow processes. The industrial partner and the PI will work in a parallel program to apply these diagnostic techniques, analysis approaches, and physical insight to actual low emissions hardware.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program is motivated by the issue of combustion thermoacoustic instabilities that plague clean power generation and aircraft propulsion systems. Left unaddressed this problem causes significant downtime, damage to hardware, increase in emissions and operation costs. The work performed over the course of this program has made transformational advances in the problem of acoustic-flame interactions that forms the heart of this combustion instability phenomena. The project has achieved its goals by using a suite of state of the art, high frequency laser diagnostics in experiments to characterize these interactions and theoretical models to better understand how different controlling components play a role in the dynamics.

A key focus of this work was understanding the inherently multi-dimensional nature of these interactions, as transverse acoustic waves excite strong helical motions.  This work has significantly added to the existing literature, which primarily focused on more axisymmetric disturbance fields encountered in longitudinal acoustics. Following this point, we developed a family of theoretical solutions for how both premixed and non-premixed flames respond to non-axisymmetric forcing. We have also utilized the measured flow field measurements described above as inputs to theoretical models to make predictions that were shown to compare well with corresponding measurements from the experiments. With these efforts, this project stands out as the first of its kind in understanding the predicting how flames response to axisymmetric disturbances and asymmetric helical flow disturbances from both experimental diagnostics and theoretical modeling standpoints. 

The project has resulted in several peer-reviewed publications including a textbook, journal articles and conference presentations. The project has also resulted in the PI giving numerous invited lectures and tutorials at different conference and workshops around the world. Apart from significant exposure and understanding of combustion instabilities, all graduate students involved in the project have received exposure to the application of the models and findings in prediction tools at industry partners, such as GE. GE has provided financial support during the course of this project to actively using results from this work as part of their design process. Several graduate students has also spent the summer at GE as part of an internship program that helped connect their research at the academic lab to the implementation and usage at GE. Graduate students have also visited local middle schools and high schools as well as hosted high school teachers at the university's research lab to expose them to the mathematical and scientific foundations that were applied to this project as well as to foster interest in working towards the issues and problems of energy and environment. Overall, this project has not only advanced the scientific understanding of transversely excited flame dynamics, but also promoted collaboration with industry partners who motivate its use in product development as well as exposed its importance to the next generation of engineers and designers.
